title: Which viewpoint is best while writing a novel; 1st person or 3rd person? - Quora

response.answer_text: Better? What is better is what works for the story, and works for you. The second is the bigger part of it. Write what is comfortable for you, and that you have the skills to do well. (Counter-intuitively, First-Person can actually be harder for a certain level of writers). And what works for the kind of story you are trying to tell? Well, I have a couple of opinions. I wouldn’t call them hard facts. More like how it has worked so far for me. First Person is harder to objectify in. Third Person is harder to do running commentary in. I’ll take the later first. Yeah, I started a book in First Person because my character was going to spend half of the book alone and I didn’t want to add a soccer ball just so they’d have someone to talk to. There’s a reason the default for Urban Fantasy has been called “First Person Snarker.” And that’s because in First Person you can make all sorts of comments and observations, explain background information, and drop pop-culture references. This just doesn’t work as smoothly in Third Person. “Sam looked at the guard’s uniform and all he could think of was Flash Gordon.” On the flip side, it is harder to be a badass in First Person. That’s part of what I meant by objectification. It is harder to torture a First Person because they can’t describe pain without sounding whiney. Whereas a Third Person can go into a blue funk and stop moving or caring, if a First Person were to do that the narration would stop. They also come out short on descriptions. Mirror gag aside (and is it ever truly aside?) a Third Person can be introduced with a terse, “He had red hair and a physics degree and had served two rotations as a Navy SEAL.” A First Person can’t make a stealth dump like that. They have to say it. And it sounds boasting if not narcissistic. I mean, a Third Person can brush their hair back or scratch an itch without giving a thought to it, but a First Person can’t do anything unconsciously. They narrate their entire lives for us. Make no mistake. With enough skill you can do the same things in either voice. They do tend to gravitate more in certain directions, though, and that might be a good reason to chose one over the other — for a specific story.

Third. It ‘sounds’ a lot better, and makes your writing sound a bit more grown up. I won’t lie, I find it very difficult to read anything in the first person. For starters, writing in the first person kinda locks you into the present tense, as ‘I did this’ and I did that’ makes it seem like the protagonist is recounting something, which is fine for dialogue, but not so much for a whole book. Present tense in itself isn’t great either, it’s kinda…I don’t really know how to explain it, but it’s kinda simple. Plus if you can change tense, you can change the pace of the story. This option would be more cumbersome if you write in the first person. Generally from what I read online, (tends to be fan-fiction type things, some original stories) first person is the style of a teenage writer, and if you’ve got that in your head while reading it, you don’t appreciate it as much. Well I don’t but I’m kinda an arsehole, so there’s that to factor in. Third person on the other hand makes you seem a bit more grown up, shows you learnt how to write in school, and you’re not writing like a sophisticated five year old. There’s also the effect on the protagonist. Writing in the first person kinda makes the protagonist a bit wishy washy character-wise. Is the protagonist going on the adventure, or is it the reader? If the reader is supposed to be going on an adventure, sure, by all means use first person, but otherwise, stick to third. Third person also means you can remind the reader of your protagonists name in a less obvious manner than someone using the name when speaking to the protagonist. Personally I write in third (except for now obviously), just cos it’s easier to switch perspectives within a chapter. For example (not my writing): Susan walks down the street. She buys bread. John walks down the street. He is out to slay a dragon Here we have clear cut perspectives from two separate characters. I walk down the street, and buy some bread I walk down the street to slay a dragon Even if there is some sort of division between these two perspectives, the reader won’t know who’s perspectives they are, which, the further into the book/writing they get, will become very annoying, the perspectives will get mixed up, it’d be a generally frustrating read. I’m no expert on this though, I’m just giving my opinion on the two persons in writing. I stick to third cos I like it better, and because my stories tend to follow multiple characters at the same time, with no ‘main’ character. Well there s a main character, but they’re not like, the protagonist. Anywho, I hope that helps answer the question, good luck with your writing :D
